title: First colored world series, opening game Oct. 11, 1924, Kansas City, Mo.
notes: Title from item. Names of players printed on the photo.
summary: Group portrait of players from the Monarchs and the Hilldale baseball teams in front of grandstands filled with spectators before the opening game in Kansas City of the 1924 World Series. This was the opening game for the two games played in Kansas City, though it is Game #5 in the series overall.

title: African American soldier, half-length portrait, with pistol and jacket
Sailor with cigar in hand holding a double case image of confederate soldiers
notes: Caption label from exhibit "American Treasures Memory": A Civil War Sailor. In need of experienced sailors during the Civil War, the United States Navy recruited free blacks and contraband into its ranks. It is estimated that 18,000 African-American sailors served in the Navy during the Civil War. Blacks worked on most of the naval vessels alongside their white counterparts and received equal pay, living accommodations, medical care, and pensions. This is an example of an ambrotype, a photographic process used for a brief period of time in the mid-1800s that placed a glass plate negative against a dark background to create a positive image.
summary: Photograph shows a three-quarter-length portrait of an African American sailor sitting, facing front, holding cased photographs toward the camera.

title: World War - in the service of the nation
creator: Smith, Dan, 1865-1934
summary: Commemorative allegorical print showing Columbia seated on pedestal, wearing a Phrygian cap, with an American flag, eagle with wings spread, and a scene showing American soldiers shooting a machine gun. Printed below the image is a certificate, "In the serivce of the nation", for a soldier's record of service, followed by an excerpt from President Woodrow Wilson's Dec. 4, 1917 speech before congress. Also shows emblems of various military service units and the flags of several nations.

title: Mansion of the rebel Genl. Thomas F. Drayton, Hilton Head, S.C.

summary: Photograph showing African American slave women and Union soldiers outside Drayton's house.

title: Fannie Virginia Casseopia Lawrence, a redeemed slave child, 5 years of age...

summary: Photograph shows full-length portrait of Fannie Lawrence, standing near a desk.

title: Slaves of the rebel Genl. Thomas F. Drayton, Hilton Head, S.C.
creator: Moore, Henry P., 1833-1911
notes: Caption label from exhibit "American Treasures Memory": Brother Against Brother. Percival Drayton was denounced by the legislature of his native South Carolina when he chose to fight for the Union during the Civil War. Given command of the USS Pocahontas, Drayton participated in the successful 1861 expedition against Port Royal, South Carolina, during which the defending troops under the command of his brother, Brigadier General Thomas Drayton were forced to withdraw inland, with the general himself leaving behind a house and slaves pictured here.
summary: Photograph showing a group portrait of African American men and women on a plantation.

creator: Stone, Fred. A.
notes: Title devired from Gladstone's collection checklist.
summary: Photograph shows group of men posed in front of of tents. Men are in uniform, some are holding instruments. Includes one African American steward in uniform with company insignia. Men in front hold the letter K.

title: Southern menagerie, stirring him up
summary: Picture shows Jefferson Davis labeled "Southern Lion, J.D." in a cage on wheels labeled "Southern Menagerie" with an African American poking him with a stick.

title: Return envelope of the Bureau of the American Freedmen's Aid Union, No. 130 Nassau-Street, New York
Black republican
summary: Picture shows an African American man wearing dress clothes, holding his hat and gloves in his hands.

title: "Jewels" found at Alexandria, by the Federal Army; consisting of chains, bracelets, and anklets. Supposed to have belonged to the "First Families" of Virginia
creator: Upham, Samuel C. (Samuel Curtis), 1819-1885
summary: Picture shows shackles, leg irons and handcuffs.

title: 4th Division, 9th Army Corps flag in green
creator: Magee, John L.
summary: Picture shows a flag of the 4th Division, 9th Army Corps.

title: Elmira rendezvous, long may it wave
summary: Picture shows the American flag above the text "Long may it Wave".

title: Wanted a $15.000.000 loan for the C.S.A.
summary: Picture shows an African American boy looking at a sign that reads "Wanted a $15.000.000 loan for the C.S.A."

title: Secession
summary: Picture shows an African American boy and mother with a bundle running.

title: I'se just "seceshed" from Ole Massa, Yah, Yah, Yah!
summary: Picture shows a caricature of an African American man dancing and holding a cigarette or cigar.

title: A Southern Gorilla, (Guerilla)
summary: Picture shows an animal dressed in a military uniform with a gun and other equipment. Includes eight lines of text.

title: Stamped envelope addressed to Lieut Edwin T. Carrington
summary: Envelope addressed to "Lieut. Edwin T. Carrington, 45 Regt. USCT, 2nd Brigade, 3rd Division, 10th Army Corps, Old Point Comfort, Virginia." Postmark is stamped "Colebrook, CT, Nov 21." Strikes are drawn through a three-cent US postage stamp.

title: Stamped envelope addressed to Capt. M. Patterson
summary: Envelope is addressed as "Capt. M. Patterson, 19th Reg. USCT, 3rd Brigade, 1st Division, 25th Army Corps, Brownsville, Texas." Strikes are drawn through a three-cent US postage stamp.

title: Contraband, Fortress Monroe
notes: Devised title from Gladstone collection checklist.
summary: Print shows a slave at the Union fort taunting his plantation master. The planter (left) waves his whip and cries, "Come back you black rascal." The slave replies, "Can't come back nohow massa Dis chile's contraban." Other slaves are seen leaving the fields and heading toward the fort. On May 27, 1861, Benjamin Butler, commander of the Union army in Virginia and North Carolina, decreed that slaves who fled to Union lines were legitimate "contraband of war," and were not subject to return to their Confederate owners. The declaration precipitated scores of escapes to Union lines around Fortress Monroe, Butler's headquarters in Virginia.

title: African American man, member of the Grand United Order of Odd Fellows, wearing fraternal order collar and apron
creator: Golsh, A. C.
summary: Photograph shows a full length portrait of an African American man, member of the Grand United Order of Odd Fellows, wearing a fraternal order collar and apron. His collar is embroidered with a three links symbol on the left and stars on each side, he  holds a sword in his left hand.

title: Alagazam, cake walk, march & two step by Abe Holzmann
creator: Holzmann, Abe, 1874-1939
summary: Picture shows African American troops marching with rifles. Used as an illustrated sheet music cover for songs written by Abe Holzmann.

title: Jefferson Davis
creator: Pendleton, William S.
summary: Photograph shows a full length portrait of Jefferson Davis, holding his hat in hand. Verso image shows the slave quarters on his plantation.

title: Unidentified Union soldier in frock coat, private, kepi, 3rd-5th buttons open on coat
Freedom for all--6th United States Colored Troops
Wounded colored soldiers at Aikens Landing
creator: E. & H.T. Anthony (Firm)
notes: On front: Photographic history The War for the Union.

title: Camp Brightwood, D.C.--Contrabands in 2nd R.I. Camp
summary: Capt. B.S. Brown (left); Lt. John P. Shaw, Co. F 2nd Regt. Rhode Island Volunteer Infantry (center); and Lt. Fry (right) with African American men and boy.

title: Charles Batties
summary: Photograph shows an African American man, Charles Batties(?), full-length portrait standing, facing front, wearing sailor uniform.

title: Watch meeting, Dec. 31, 1862--Waiting for the hour
creator: Heard & Moseley
summary: African American men, women, and children gathered around a man with a watch, waiting for the Emancipation Proclamation.

title: Buffalo soldiers of the 25th Infantry, some wearing buffalo robes, Ft. Keogh, Montana
notes: "#5. Some of the coons that are in camp at Keogh taken Sunday morning, Dec. 14th '90" handwritten inscription in red ink on back.

title: Camp Lincoln
summary: African American man, full-length portrait, standing in front of tent, facing front, wearing military uniform, holding rifle.

title: 803rd Pioneer Infantry Battalion on the U.S.S. Philippine from Brest harbor, France, July 18, 1919]. no. 16, 803rd Pioneer Infantry band
notes: Set title from Gladstone collection checklist. Caption from item.
summary: Photograph shows African American band members on the U.S.S. Philippine, during voyage to the United States from Brest, France, 1919.

title: Sojourner Truth
summary: Photograph shows Sojourner Truth in a three-quarter-length portrait. She is sitting at table with knitting and a book.

title: Sojourner Truth
summary: Photograph shows Sojourner Truth, head-and-shoulders portrait, facing slightly left.

title: 24th Infantry Leaving Salt Lake City, Utah for Chattanooga, Tennessee, April 24th, 1898
summary: African American soldiers marching down main street, while pedestrians look on.
